user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_bus_close:
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
...
#define for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) for((ldrv)=lbus->drivers;(ldrv)->drv_name;(ldrv)++)
...
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...
struct linux_driver {
	const char		*drv_name;
	const char		*mod_name;
	const char		*cls_name;
	struct sysfs_driver	*sdrv;
	int			(*dev_open)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					    struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_close)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_irq_ack)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev,
					     int irq);
	int			(*dev_dma_map)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg_in,
						int nents_in,
						struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void			(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg,
						int nents);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function metal_linux_bus_close and all related definitions. There are no uses of the standard library function memcmp anywhere in the target function, the for_each_linux_driver macro, or the linux_bus/linux_driver/to_linux_bus definitions. The only string-like field referenced is drv_name, but it is tested as a pointer in the macro ((ldrv)->drv_name) — a null-pointer check used as loop sentinel, not a comparison of null-terminated strings via memcmp. No other string-comparison operations or calls to memcmp are present in the supplied code, so there are no fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
